awd_titl_txt: An integrated experimental and computational study of erythrocyte adhesion mechanics in blood flows
awd_abstract_narration:
When red blood cells stick to the walls of blood vessels, a number of potentially life-threatening health problems can be created, including sickle-cell anemia, malaria, and diabetes. Currently, our understanding of how red blood cell properties influence their stickiness is limited. This research project combines theory, mathematical models and experiments to try to develop an accurate description of the mechanisms that lead to cell adhesion to blood vessel walls.  The researchers involved in this project are participating in an existing outreach program that engages high school students from local disadvantaged communities in research opportunities, lab tours, and guest lectures. YouTube videos and workshops targeted at the general population are further extending the understanding of this work to a broader audience, as are the development and delivery of experimental modules related to this project. This flexible educational and training program is intended to help develop the workforce needed to address expanding demands in the field of biomedical science and healthcare. 

The central hypothesis of this study is that erythrocyte deformability is a key factor in cell attachment and detachment processes, wherein low-deformability cells have more stable contact with the adhesion molecules, which enhances the adhesion strength of erythrocyte to endothelium. To verify the hypothesis, the specific research aims of this project are: (i) to derive a fundamental understanding of the fluid mechanics in the vicinity of erythrocyte endothelium interactions by a novel monolithic Lagrangian Fluid-Structure Interaction model and micro-Particle Image Velocimetry experiments in microfluidic channels, and quantify the lift and drag forces on the deformable cells exerted by the plasma under different flow conditions; (ii) to use integrated microfluidic experiments and cell-scale Fluid-Structure Interaction simulations to characterize the mechanical properties and deformability of healthy and unhealthy cells in physiological conditions; and (iii) to qualitatively and quantitatively describe the influence of cell deformability on the underlying physics of flowing erythrocyte adhesion to immobilized endothelium proteins by a combination of three-dimensional direct cell simulations in plasma and microfluidic experiments. The researchers are focusing on better understanding the sensitivities of the shape, deformability and membrane properties of cells, the type and density of receptor-ligand bonds, as well as the physiological shear rates of plasma, on the dynamic strength of erythrocyte-endothelium adhesion. This project will advance the knowledge base in computational science, biomechanics and develop new experimental technologies to treat vascular disease.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we have developed a number of numerical methods to solve the biofluids-cell interaction problems. In specific, a monolithic fluid structure interaction algorithm was proposed to overcome challenges in the traditional FSI framework, including convergence and stability issues. In this framework, the continuum domain is discretized and solved by the Optimal Transportation Meshfree (OTM) method. A uniform set of governing equations in the Lagrangian configuration are adopted to describe both the fluid (e.g., plasma and cytoplasm) and solid domain (e.g., RBCs membrane). The fluid structure interfaces become an internal surface which automatically ensures the continuity and force equilibrium and leads to a more stable and accurate solution with fast convergence. Moreover, the use of Lagrangian formulations for fluid eliminates the problem of free surface and interface tracking and generates symmetric system matrices due to the absence of the convective terms. Specifically, a single RBC adherent to the substrate of the microfluidic device as well as the surrounding blood flow is simulated simultaneously in OTM method. Moreover, three dimensional RBC structure is modeled as a combination of RBC membrane and cytoplasm and is implemented in the OTM FSI method, which improves the computational efficiency dramatically. Adhesion nodes are pre-defined in RBC membrane surface in order to predict the shape change of RBC under blood flow. The parallel solver based on the Message Passing Interface (MPI) is employed to overcome the high computational cost due to large volumes of nodal discretization. The proposed FSI algorithms in this project are transformative and address many difficulties in the conventional partitioning FSI methods, which promotes the application of high-fidelity computational models in the study of complex biofluids.

On the other hand, we present a constant shear microfluidic platform functionalized with endothelium-associated adhesion molecules (fibronectin) to assess deformability of red blood cells (RBCs) with normal (Habra) and sickle (HbSS) hemoglobin. Furthermore, we have developed a microfluidic system integrated with a micro particle image velocimetry (PIV) technique to assess whole blood viscosity (WBV) in vitro. The experimental results enabled us to validate the numerical prediction of the fluid flow surrounding cells. This platform is capable of analyzing the change of RBC deformability at different shear rates simultaneously. By comparing the fluid condition and RBC shape between experiments and simulations, fidelity of the developed numerical framework can be validated.

We proposed an integrated experimental and computational approach to quantify the different cell biomechanical properties to reveal the influence of cell deformability on the underlying physics of RBC-endothelium adhesion and detachment process. The micro-fluidic experiments are performed for both healthy RBC, and sickle RBC under the same inflow velocity, the geometric shape change of the RBC is measured and used to determine RBC membrane properties by using machine learning algorithms and FSI simulations. Both the specific material properties of healthy RBC and sickle RBC from a single patient can be obtained based on this integrated approach. Also, RBC-Fibronectin adhesion experiments are performed using the sickle cell from the same patient under various flow conditions. We mainly focus on the FN fiber, which exhibits an extraordinary ability to elongate under cell adhesion and is highly heterogeneous in structure and conformation.   We proposed a viscoelastic constitutive model to describe the dynamic behavior of the cell-FN binder during cell deformation and separation, due to the molecular structure unraveling and the breakage of molecular hydrogen bonds as well as the conformation change to peptide chains. By utilizing this novel computational framework integrated with microfluidic platform, we have derived a high efficient methodology to reveal the underlying mechanics of RBC adhesion and detachment process. The central hypothesis of this proposal is verified that RBC deformability is a key factor in cell attachment and detachment processes, wherein low-deformability RBCs have more stable contact with the adhesion molecules and undermine the local forces to deform and separate the binders, which enhances the adhesion strength of RBCs to endothelium. The overall goal of the proposal is successfully completed during the three-year project period.

 


Last Modified: 07/24/2022
Modified by: Bo Li
